channel.title: NPR Topics: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.

item.title: Venezuelans wonder who's in charge as Trump claims contact with Maduro's deputy
item.description: Venezuelans scrambled to understand who was in charge of their country after the U.S. captured Nicolás Maduro. President Trump offered an answer: The United States would take control of Venezuela.
item.content:encoded:
Venezuelans scrambled to understand who was in charge of their country after the U.S. captured Nicolás Maduro. President Trump offered an answer: The United States would take control of Venezuela.

(Image credit: Ariana Cubillos)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Who is María Corina Machado, Venezuela's Nobel Peace Prize winning opposition leader?
item.description: The United States has captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro. Opposition leader María Corina Machado has been one of his biggest critics.
item.content:encoded:
The United States has captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro. Opposition leader María Corina Machado has been one of his biggest critics.

(Image credit: Stian Lysberg Solum)
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: In Miami, Venezuelans hail U.S. move against Maduro
item.description: Miami has the largest population of Venezuelan ex-pats. Hundreds of people turned out to cheer the news that U.S. authorities took custody of President Nicolas Maduro.
item.content:encoded: Miami has the largest population of Venezuelan ex-pats. Hundreds of people turned out to cheer the news that U.S. authorities took custody of President Nicolas Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Greg Allen

item.title: Trump says the U.S. will run Venezuela after U.S. seizes Maduro
item.description: President Trump details U.S. plans in Venezuela in the wake of a controversial mission to remove and indict President Maduro.
item.content:encoded: President Trump details U.S. plans in Venezuela in the wake of a controversial mission to remove and indict President Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: What we know about the military operation to capture Maduro
item.description: Details are emerging about how U.S. forces entered Venezuela and seized President Nicolas Maduro.
item.content:encoded: Details are emerging about how U.S. forces entered Venezuela and seized President Nicolas Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Mary Louise Kelly

item.title: Former US Ambassador to Venezuela reacts to U.S. operation to seize Nicolas Maduro
item.dc:creator: Mary Louise Kelly

item.title: Regional and global reactions to the operation in Venezuela
item.description: Leaders around the world react to the U.S. operation in Venezuela.
item.content:encoded: Leaders around the world react to the U.S. operation in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Eyder Peralta

item.title: What to know about the U.S. strikes in Venezuela — and the fallout
item.description: President Trump said the U.S. would "run" Venezuela, following the capture of President Nicolás Maduro on Saturday. But many questions remain about what's next.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump said the U.S. would "run" Venezuela, following the capture of President Nicolás Maduro on Saturday. But many questions remain about what's next.

(Image credit: Jesus Vargas)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Venezuela's government rejects U.S. claims as Caracas shows loyalty to Maduro
item.description: Venezuela's state media condemns the capture of President Nicolás Maduro as pro-government rallies and armed civilian patrols emerge in Caracas.
item.content:encoded: Venezuela's state media condemns the capture of President Nicolás Maduro as pro-government rallies and armed civilian patrols emerge in Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Carrie Kahn

item.title: Six questions about the capture of Maduro
item.description: On a day when most reporters are chasing facts, NPR's Morning Edition host Steve Inskeep has a few questions.
item.content:encoded:
On a day when most reporters are chasing facts, NPR's Morning Edition host Steve Inskeep has a few questions.

(Image credit: Matias Delacroix)
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep
